article_title: The Berber Dahir and the Rise of Moroccan Nationalism

paragraphs.text: In the early 20th century, Morocco was a land of diverse cultures and languages, including Arabic and Berber (also known as Amazigh) . The Alawite dynasty theoretically united the country, but in practice, Morocco consisted of numerous small, independent states . The Sultan's authority was largely confined to cities and major routes, with religious fiefdoms, temporal principalities, and Berber republics also existing . The French Protectorate was established in 1912 through the Treaty of Fez, placing Morocco under French control while ceding a coastal area along the Strait of Gibraltar to Spain . This treaty allowed France to occupy parts of Morocco under the guise of protecting the sovereign . The French Resident-General gained the sole right to represent Morocco in foreign countries .

Prior to the French Protectorate, Spain and France had been vying for influence in Morocco . The Act of Algeciras in 1906 granted France partial control of customs and the National Bank of Morocco . The French colonial administration, under Marshal Lyautey, aimed to modernize the country while preserving its traditions . However, this approach was not always consistent, and tensions arose between the French administration and Moroccan society .

On May 16, 1930, the French Protectorate authorities promulgated the Berber Dahir (also referred to as the Berber Decree), a decree that formalized the tribal law system (droit coutumier) in Berber-dominant rural areas of Morocco . The Dahir divided the French Protectorate into zones governed by Sharia law and Berber customary law . It aimed to adapt Berber justice to modern conditions, following the spirit of the Dahir of September 11, 1914, signed by Lyautey . The policy sought to preserve Berber autonomy, especially in legal matters, by keeping them outside Islamic law (Chrâa) and maintaining their customary law (Orf or Izref) . The administration was tasked with defining Berber laws and designating Berber tribes, primarily based on submission to military authorities .

The Dahir also imposed the supremacy of French law in Berber regions . Article 6 of the Dahir Berbère stated that French courts were competent to repress crimes committed in Berber regions regardless of the status of the perpetrator .

The Berber Dahir was met with widespread opposition from Moroccan nationalists, who viewed it as an attempt to divide the country and Christianize the Berbers . Nationalists framed the Dahir as an attempt to abolish Islamic law . The decree was seen as an assault on Muslim identity . The protests against the Berber Dahir began in Salé a few weeks after its promulgation, centered around the recitation of the latif, a collective prayer invoking God in situations of disaster . The protests spread from Salé to other cities like Rabat, Fez, and Casablanca .

The protests helped to unify an emerging Moroccan nationalist movement . The national movement was founded on the sentiment of belonging to the Islamic community and the Arab nation . The feeling of belonging to the Muslim community (al-ummat al-islamîya) was a dominant factor in this nationalism . The protests took place during a period of economic uncertainty, including the global crisis of 1929 and local issues like droughts and locust plagues .

The protests in Salé were initiated by a group of young men, aged 17-25, who were active in cultural institutions with proto-nationalist leanings . Abdelatif Subihi, an employee of the colonial administration and graduate of the School of Oriental Languages in Paris, played a key role in initiating the protests in Salé . The anniversary of the Berber Dahir on May 16th was commemorated annually with gatherings in mosques to recite the latif .

The Berber Dahir also drew international attention and condemnation . Chakib Arsalan, a prominent Druze Syrian and advocate of pan-Arabism, visited Morocco in 1930 and promoted the Moroccan struggle in his newspaper La Nation Arabe . In January 1931, 12 Islamic associations in Java created a Muslim Committee for the defense of the Berbers . The Islamic Congress of Jerusalem in December 1931 approved a declaration calling on France to withdraw the Dahir . Letters of protest were sent from the Pan-Islamic Congress and the Associations of Young Muslims from other regions of the Arab world .

sections.subtitle: French Responses and the Dahir's Legacy

paragraphs.text: The French authorities responded to the protests with repression, arresting and exiling nationalist leaders . However, they also attempted to address some of the concerns raised by the protests . In 1934, Article 6 of the Berber Dahir was repealed, uniformizing penal jurisdictions .

Despite this abrogation, the French Berber policy continued . The Berber Dahir remained in effect until 1956 . The Sultán criticized the manipulation of the Latif by young nationalists in August 11 . On August 27, 1930 a delegation of nationalists visited the Sultan in Fez to deliver a memorandum . The Berber Dahir contributed to giving the Moroccan national movement unity and coherence . The monolingual identity of Morocco was decided in the 1930s after the Berber Dahir .

sections.subtitle: The Berber Dahir as a Foundational Myth

paragraphs.text: The protests against the Berber Dahir have been framed as a foundational myth of Moroccan nationalism . The Dahir was framed by nationalists as an attempt to divide the country and Christianize the Berbers . The young men came up with a powerful counter narrative about Moroccan culture and identity, stressing the unity of the nation founded on Islam and Arabism . The Berber Dahir unified salafi and nationalist sentiments and was viewed as an assault on Muslim identity .

sections.subtitle: The Aftermath and the Amazigh Movement

paragraphs.text: After independence in 1956, the three legal zones, French, Spanish and International, were brought under one common legal regime . Allal al-Fasi strived to create a new legislation based on Islamic law, understood according to the reformist ideals of the neo-salafiyya movement . The Moroccan State's ambiguous politics of Arabisation in the aftermath of independence in 1956 .

The marginalization of Berber language and culture continued in the post-colonial era, leading to the rise of the Amazigh movement . The Amazigh movement aims to recognize the impact of Amazigh culture on Moroccan history and the importance of the Tamazight language . The Amazigh movement has achieved successes, including the creation of the IRCAM (a government institution dedicated to Amazigh culture) and the recognition of Tamazight as an official language .

In 1994, King Hassan II of Morocco publicly addressed the 'Berber question' and advocated for teaching Berber dialects in schools . The Royal Institute of Amazigh Culture (IRCAM) was established in Morocco in 2001 to promote Berber culture and language . The Moroccan constitution of 2011 recognized Tamazight as an official language . The 2011 constitution states that Morocco's national identity is based on the convergence of Arab-Islamic, Amazigh, and Saharan components, along with African, Andalusian, Hebrew, and Mediterranean influences .

Despite these advancements, challenges remain . Attempts to form a Berber political party in Morocco in 2015 were blocked by the government . Institutionalized discrimination against Amazigh ethnicities and their languages in Morocco persists .
